isis.stitle: AIR COMPRESSOR: HOLSET SS 296 AND QE 296/338 - TROUBLESHOOTING

entry.para: Condition
Cause
Remedy
Compressor will not build up air pressure or has slow buildup
Vehicle plumbing leakage.
Check for ruptured lines and loose or cracked fittings.
Sticking unloader valve.
Check, clean and lube with high temperature grease in the kit.
Broken intake or exhaust valve.
Replace intake or exhaust valve. Check for cause of failure (discharge line blocked).
Governor fails to exhaust air from unloader.
Replace governor. Be sure control line is open.
Automatic spitter on wet tank sticking open.
Service or replace as necessary.
Compressor discharge and wet tank supply hoses reversed at air dryer.
Reverse the hoses.
Air dryer purge valve leaking.
Clean or replace if necessary.
Air dryer purge valve frozen open.
Thaw valve and test dryer heater and thermostat, power, and ground. Replace if necessary.
Blown or leaking head gasket.
Replace cover, head and valve body gaskets. Check for cause of blown gasket (loose head bolts, restricted discharge, carbon, ice, etc.).
Kinked or restricted air intake (20 inches water is maximum vacuum allowable).
Check and correct as necessary.
Damaged intake or exhaust seat of valve body, or debris holding valve open.
Check for damage or debris. Service and correct as necessary.
Carbon buildup: exhaust line, ECON valve, or dryer inlet.
Clean and replace affected parts. Check exhaust line and replace if necessary. Duty cycle may be excessive (over 25%).
Compressor builds too much air pressure
Defective governor will not send air pressure signal to unloader.
Replace governor.
Unloader cap stuck in loaded position.
Remove, clean and lubricate well with high temperature grease in the kit. Replace if necessary.
Unloader valve body vee seal broken or worn.
Replace unloader valve body vee seal.
Pressure builds slowly above governor limit
Unloader cap seat leak.
Repair or replace unloader cap.
Cracked/porous inlet connection body.
Replace the inlet connection body.
Leak at air intake gasket between valve body and inlet connection body.
Tighten mounting bolts to specified torque or replace air intake gasket.
Mechanical noise in compressor
Too much backlash in drive coupling or gear.
Adjust mounting position of compressor ( ONLY WITH ENGINE COLD!).
Pneumatic noise or ping in air tank
Single cylinder air pulse into tanks (air delivery is normal).
If the noise is objectionable, a ping tank can be installed between the compressor and wet tank.
Compressor cycles frequently-CAB PRESSURE GAUGES FALL TO BOTTOM OF GOVERNOR RANGE
Brake, accessory, or suspension leaks.
Locate and correct the leaks. Check for stuck valves.
Excessive demand duty cycle (pumping over 25% of the time).
Reduce air system demands or use greater output compressor.
Compressor cycles frequently-DRY TANK'S (CAB GAUGES) PRESSURE REMAINS NEAR TOP OF GOVERNOR RANGE
Air dryer outlet check valve leaks. (Approximately 30 second cycle)
Repair, lubricate or replace air dryer outlet check valve.
HINT: Check the dryer's discharge check valve by adding a known good check valve at the dryer's outlet port. If this makes a difference, the dryer's check valve is not working right.

note.para: The vehicle air system should be checked regularly for air leaks by timing the interval between dryer purge blasts, while the vehicle is stationary with engine idling and with no air system demands, or from start-to-start of compressor pumping intervals, if there is no air dryer. Times of ten minutes or more are desirable between dryer purge blasts. Times noticeably shorter indicate significant air system leakage from the vehicle's wet tank, or from something connected to the wet tank.

entry.para: Incorrect check valve in the makeup line, so that ECON valve malfunctions. (Approx. 3 minute cycle)
Replace with Holset differential check valve. Dryers without internal inlet cut-off valve may use non-Holset check valve in makeup line.
Leaks from items connected to the wet tank. (Approx. 3 to 7 minute cycle)
Use soap bubbles to locate leaks: fittings, sensing line to governor, governor to compressor gasket or hose, signal hose from governor to dryer and/or ECON valve, and makeup line.
HINT: Let system pump to top of governor range so that signal hose will be pressurized, then start checking for leaks.
ECON valve leaking-because of debris or carbon on the seat.
Clean or replace the ECON valve.

HINT: If air continues to escape from the purge port of the dryer for more than a minute after purge begins, and the known good redundant check valve has been added at the dryer's outlet port, then leakage past the ECON valve (and the dryer's internal boost cut-off valve, if there is one) is likely the source of continued air escape beyond the normal purge air release (30 to 45 seconds is typical). This will cause short cycles, desiccant saturation and then possible freezing problems inside the ECON valve.
Air dryer internal inlet cut-off valve leaks with result similar to that of leaking ECON valve.
Clean or replace the valve at the dryer inlet.
HINT: Several dryers now have an internal inlet f valve with elastomeric seat, which takes the place of an external ECON valve.
Excessive oil carryover into air system
Excessive duty cycle (pumping more than 25% of time running)
Reduce legitimate air system needs, repair leaks, or up-size compressor.
Check for leak at dryer spitter port during loaded mode. Replace dryer spitter valve.
Check for holes rubbed in discharge line.
Runs hot.
Check and repair coolant circuit. Consider duty cycle.

HINT: Consider overall cycle time. A short cycle time while tank gauges remain near top of range indicates severe leak or dryer outlet check valve malfunction. High duty cycles result in air compressor doing more work and operating at elevated temperature, which thins oil on cylinder wall and aggravates oil carryover. Carbon deposits indicate that the compressor is running too hot.
HINT: Check for discharge line pressure above 135 psi due to excessive restriction between compressor and wet tank or misadjustment of the air governor.
HINT: Check for pumping longer than one minute with inlet pressure above 10 psi and outlet pressure above 100 psi.
HINT: Verify that compressor discharge line is connected to dryer inlet, not outlet, which would result in high back pressure and long buildup times with E-type system.

HINT: A leaking compressor exhaust valve or a leaking discharge line will cause both the slow buildup and rapid decay of wet tank pressure, which may not be noticed by checking cycle time alone, since cycle time is the sum of buildup and decay times. But the duty cycle will be very high and the compressor will run hot!
Failure to maintain discharge line pressure near system pressure during unloaded operating mode.

HINT: The patented E-type compressor system requires near wet tank pressure to deliver the benefits of reduced power consumption, lower operating temperature, and superior oil control during unloaded operation.
Check to assure that a check valve has not been installed at the entrance to the wet tank, preventing the supplying of wet tank pressure to the discharge line when there is no air dryer.

Inspect differential or other check valve located in the makeup line to assure it is in good working condition and not installed backwards. Check valve must permit flow toward inlet side of air dryer.

Check to be sure the makeup line and check valve are not plugged. With the engine off, loosen the makeup line at the entrance to the ECON valve or dryer inlet if there is no ECON valve. Air should escape from the makeup line. If no air escapes from the loosened fitting, bleed off wet tank pressure, and remove the makeup line and check valve for further inspection. Be careful! If a check valve is broken, look for its parts which could block the makeup line.
When there is a dryer without internal "makeup" line, there must be an external makeup line which includes a check valve which permits air to flow from wet tank to the inlet side of the air dryer.
No ECON valve.

Add ECON valve, or use an air dryer which has an internal inlet cutoff valve with elastomeric seat capable of holding full system pressure. Some means of sealing the downstream end of discharge line must be provided to maintain system pressure in the discharge line during unloaded compressor operation. Dryers with internal elastomeric inlet cutoff valve have the advantage of a heated valve where condensation is less likely to freeze during extremely cold weather operation.
Cylinder bore or piston ring wear, scoring, or bore polishing.
Check air intake plumbing and filter for any source of contaminant ingestion. Replace rings or the entire compressor.
Piston rings improperly installed or broken.
Repair or replace compressor.
Excessive engine oil drain intervals.
Change oil at proper intervals to avoid the breakdown of multi-viscosity oils. Broken long-chain polymers aggravate oil carryover in the air compressor, just like oil burning in the engine.
Abnormal amount of moisture in the wet tank
Check valve missing or backwards.

Sometimes, it happens. Some check valves look like a fitting and vice versa. The main purpose of the check valve is to prevent air from bypassing the air dryer and thus, carrying moisture to wet tank.
Air dryer saturated/ineffective.
Excessive duty cycle/long-duration, short purge, desiccant "poisoned" by oil, inlet air too hot (over 150 degrees F) or spitter blocked.
Leaks: air-to-coolant or coolant-to- air.
Inadequate clamp load on head or cover gasket.
Tighten head bolts to specified torque. Chase threads at center of valve body. Replace valve body, head and cover gaskets.
Air system freeze-up - Flow path blockage with compressor damage the likely result
Low spots (potential water/ice traps) in compressor discharge line.

The discharge line should slope downward from the compressor to the dryer inlet. (An immediate rise within the first two feet of the line is acceptable if this allows the following line to slope downward to dryer inlet for drainage.)
Condensation accumulates and freezes at ECON valve.

If an ECON valve is necessary, locate it where condensation will not form upstream and where discharge air temperature is below 150 degrees F. This will usually be two to seven feet from the compressor if the dryer is more than eight to ten feet from the compressor.
Long discharge line causes condensation which freezes.
If the discharge line length must exceed ten feet, then consider insulating after the first five feet. NOTE: 150 degrees F is maximum dryer inlet temperature.
Air system freeze-up - Moisture in wet tank spreads throughout air system, causing valves to malfunction
Maximum dryer inlet temperature exceeded.
The discharge line arrangement should reduce A/C outlet air temperature to 150 degrees F maximum. Otherwise, the desiccant's water-holding efficiency will be degraded.
Dryer does not purge.
Dryer may not be receiving the required signal from the governor due to a bad governor, or a plugged or badly leaking actuating line.

Dryer may have a frozen purge port due to faulty heater, thermostat or improper electrical ground. Check the dryer's heater and thermostat to be sure they are functioning properly, not just that there is power present and that there is a good ground path. In general, there must be a reasonable electrical resistance from heater power supply contact to ground for a 50 to 100 watt heater when the dryer is cooled below thermostat closure temperature. Look for about 1.5 to 3.0 ohms for a 12 volt system.
Check valve backwards.
Reverse the check valve if it is backwards.
Leaks from the wet tank, brake or suspension system.
Locate and repair the leaks.

Design demand excessive (Long Duration Pumping Cycle). Under occasionally adverse operating conditions, the sum of the air system demands may become excessive. Wet tank pressure may not reach the top of the governor range/dryer purge point for a long time!
Check the air dryer. Replace if necessary. If the dryer becomes saturated and the system gets wet, a continuous flow dryer may improve performance.
Air dryer outlet check ball malfunctioning.

The check ball hangs open allowing wet tank pressure to be lost through the dryer purge port. Pressure falls to the bottom of the governor range in a few seconds. The air compressor is forced to resume pumping after these few seconds. The purge volume of the dryer is never allowed to do its job of drying the desiccant. The dryer becomes saturated. The compressor runs hot and suffers a premature failure. Be alert for dryer purge blasts about 30 seconds apart at idle with water in the wet tank. The dryer outlet check valve must be replaced or serviced. Contact dryer manufacturer for advice. Silicone grease on the ball is one possible temporary solution.
Condensation in wet tank.

Make it a habit to regularly (daily) drain all of the system tanks. This will minimize the spread of moisture to system valves and help you avoid serious problems. It may also allow the origin of the problem to be identified and corrected to avoid or minimize downtime.
Air dryer purge volume too small.
Dryer purge volume needs to be sufficient for the application. High air demand (by design or by leaks not corrected) may require larger or supplementary purge volume to adequately dry the desiccant.
Air demand beyond the rated capacity of the air dryer.

Consider the addition of another dryer in parallel, or a dryer with greater capacity to successfully remove moisture at the demand flow rate. All air dryers have a maximum rated air handling capacity which should be matched with the compressor output capability for a successful application.
